cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:21

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: The economic benefit of information is what distinguishes “business” confidential information from “personal” or “private” confidential information. The fact that information is valuable to its holder[1] and to competitors has often been used as a rationale in offering protection.[2] If information, through disclosure to a competitor, “would be likely to cause real (or significant) harm to the owner”, it is worthy of protection.[3] Likewise, it is clear that those entrusted with information often seek to become competitors once they realize the value of the information.[4]

In Drake International Inc. v. Tennenbaum,[5] the court held that information regarding “field staff and the matching of appropriate customers” was confidential, specifically noting that the information contained therein was “a valuable trade asset of the plaintiff which is deserving of protection”.
In another case, Reliable Toy Co. v. Collins,[6] a key fact considered by the court was that the defendant's own reports had stated that:

… the matters in question in this action were secret and this was important in a highly competitive industry where it was essential that one competitor should not know how another competitor was achieving an end result, e.g. low-cost, rapid production of a decorated styrene toy.
Reliable also demonstrates that the courts have tended to require “specifics” as to the confidential information to be protected:

The plaintiffs' advantage in this respect consisted essentially of three things: (i) being able to colour their own styrene; (ii) the possession of a process developed by them for making relatively inexpensive masks for use in decorating toys by the use of spray guns on an assembly line; and (iii) the possession of a suitable lacquer for use in conjunction with assembly line methods.[7]

In Napier Environmental Technologies Inc. v. Vitomir,[8] the court held that the allegations against the defendants were serious but that they were framed so generally as to preclude the defendants from knowing exactly what information Napier considered to be confidential.

In Consolidated Textiles Ltd. v. Central Dynamics Ltd.,[9] the Federal Court acknowledged the importance of secrecy in maintaining a competitive edge over others.[10] In that case, a third party obtained information relating to the conversion of standard fly-shuttle looms to water-jet looms. Until Consolidated Textiles developed the converted machinery, no other manufacturing company or member of the textile industry had been successful in the process. Citing numerous authorities on the misuse of confidential information, the court had little difficulty in finding that the information had been treated by the plaintiff as strictly confidential, and that such secrecy had been of significant competitive advantage to the plaintiff:

It is clear that the longer these matters could be concealed from its competitors the longer the plaintiff might expect to enjoy the competitive advantage afforded by the increased efficiency of the converted loom over the standard shuttle loom, without having to disburse the very large amount of capital required to re-equip its mills with regular water-jet looms such as those produced by Nissan.[11]

In another case, Chevron Standard Ltd. v. Home Oil Co.,[12] the court concluded that while Leeson, the plaintiff's former chief development geologist, had a general knowledge of some of the information in question, the defendant had not “gained any advantage or confidential information as a result”. The court concluded that:

On the whole of the evidence I cannot find that Leeson divulged any trade secrets to [the Defendant] or any of its employees or agents. Leeson did not disclose to [the corporate defendant] or any of its employees or agents the fact that [the plaintiff] had found seismic anomalies believed to be pinnacle reefs of Upper Devonian age. I am satisfied that Leeson did not know the location of Chevron's anomalies and, further, that he did not reveal to anyone where he thought the anomalies might be located.[13]

Finally, LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resouces Ltd.[14] implicitly acknowledged the value of the confidential information obtained by the plaintiff: “It put Lac in a preferred position vis-à-vis others with respect to knowledge of acquiring the Williams property” (emphasis added).

As the place of information in the modern economy continues to expand, the law will increasingly recognize the importance of protecting valuable information. For an interesting overview of the historical position of information at law, see G. Klueck, “The Coming Jurisprudence of the Information Age: Examinations of the Three Past Socio-Economic Ages Suggest the Future” (1984), 21 San Diego L. Rev. 1077. As one of the central means of creating wealth in modern times, information has become widely recognized as the central resource of the modern economy. See generally J. Naisbitt, Megatrends, Ten New Directions Transforming Our Lives (New York: Warner Books, 1984), pp. 6-11: “In an information economy … value is increased, not by labour, but by knowledge”; D. Tapscott and A. Caston, Paradigm Shift, The New Promise of Information Technology (New York: McGraw-Hill, 1993), p. 5: “Information … has become a capital good. It is becoming similar in value to labour, materials, and financial resources”; P.F. Drucker, Post-Capitalist Society (New York: HarperBusiness, 1993), pp. 7-8: “The basic economic resource … is no longer capital, nor natural resources … nor ‘labour’. It is and will be knowledge … Value is now created by ‘productivity’ and ‘innovaiton’, both applications of knowledge to work”; A. Toffler, Powershift (New York: Bantam, 1990), p. 91: “Because it reduces the need for raw materials, labour, time, space and capital, knowledge becomes the central resource of the advanced economy. And as this happens, its value soars.”

See generally Polyresins Ltd. v. Stein-Hall Ltd. (1971), 25 D.L.R. (3d) 152, [1972] 2 O.R. 188 (H.C.J.); Haessler-DeWay Ltd. v. Color Tech Inc. (1985), 4 C.I.P.R. 77, 49 C.P.C. 156 (Ont. Dist. Ct.). This element may be particularly important in the context of an injunction: see, for example, Eli Lilly Canada Inc. v. Shamrock Chemicals Ltd. (1985), 6 C.I.P.R. 5, 4 C.P.R. (3d) 196 (Ont. S.C.).
Lansing Linde Ltd. v. Kerr, [1991] 1 All E.R. 418 (C.A.). See also Kent Building Supplies, a division of J.D. Irving Ltd. v. Magasin du Ridge Ltée (2004), 275 N.B.R. (2d) 6 (Q.B.).

See, for example, Gemologists International Inc. v. Gem Scan International Inc. (1986), 7 C.I.P.R. 225, 10 C.P.R. (3d) 431 (Ont. H.C.J.); DCF Systems Ltd. v. Gellman (1978), 5 B.L.R. 98, 41 C.P.R. (2d) 145 (Ont. H.C.J.).

Drake International Inc. v. Tennenbaum (1986), 10 C.P.R. (3d) 119 (Ont. H.C.J.), at p. 121. See also Management Recruiters of Toronto Ltd. v. Bagg (1970), 1 C.P.R. (2d) 18, 1970 CarswellOnt 632 (Ont. S.C.); Computer Centre Personnel Ltd. v. Lagopoulos (1975), 58 D.L.R. (3d) 352, 1975 CarswellOnt 390 (Ont. H.C.); Drake International Ltd. v. Miller (1975), 61 D.L.R. (3d) 420, 1975 CarswellOnt 463 (Ont. H.C.).
Reliable Toy Co. v. Collins, [1950] 4 D.L.R. 499 at p. 520, [1950] O.R. 360 (H.C.).
Reliable Toy Co. v. Collins, [1950] 4 D.L.R. 499, [1950] O.R. 360 (H.C.).
Napier Environmental Technologies Inc. v. Vitomir (2002), 114 A.C.W.S. (3d) 1093, 2002 BCSC 1026.
Consolidated Textiles Ltd. v. Central Dynamics Ltd., [1974] 2 F.C. 814, 18 C.P.R. (2d) 1 (T.D.).
See also Sun Dial Corp. v. Rideout, 16 N.J. 252, 257, 108 A.2d 442 (1954).

Consolidated Textiles Ltd. v. Central Dynamics Ltd., [1974] 2 F.C. 814, at p. 828, 18 C.P.R. (2d) 1 (T.D.). See also Ken Graham Consumer Products Ltd. v. Sunbeam Corp. (Canada) Ltd. (1989), 25 C.P.R. (3d) 52 (Ont. H.C.J.), at p. 77.
Chevron Standard Ltd. v. Home Oil Co., [1980] 5 W.W.R. 624, 22 A.R. 451 (Q.B.), affd [1982] 3 W.W.R. 427, 35 A.R. 550 (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 50 A.R. 180n, 67 C.P.R. (2d) 16n.

Chevron Standard Ltd. v. Home Oil Co., [1980] 5 W.W.R. 624, at p. 665, 22 A.R. 451 (Q.B.), affd [1982] 3 W.W.R. 427, 35 A.R. 550 (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 50 A.R. 180n, 67 C.P.R. (2d) 16n.

LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd. (1986), 61 D.L.R. (4th) 14, [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574. The decision in Visagie v. TVX Gold Inc. (1998), 42 B.L.R. (2d) 53 (Ont. Ct. (Gen. Div.)), affd 187 D.L.R. (4th) 193, 49 O.R. (3d) 198 (C.A.), shows the importance of being able to demonstrate that there is both an entitlement to use acquired information and that such information was not confidential.
